newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Key Brazil soy ports resume loading at slower pace.
newsitem.headline: Key Brazil soy ports resume loading at slower pace.

text.p: The key Brazilian ports of Paranagua and Santos said operators were loading grains at their export terminals whenever rains stopped, although it was happening in dribs and drabs.
Both ports suspended grain loading late Monday and early Tuesday because of heavy rains.
At Paranagua, operators were loading on a stop-start basis as the weather allowed, an official said.
Meanwhile, at Santos the vessel Mentese finished loading earlier in the day and was due to leave at 1700 local time, the port authority said.
"The vessel had very little left to load and it completed loading earlier today. The weather has improved slightly," a spokeswoman at Santos said.
Both ports said it was common to halt grain loading every time it rains to avoid wetting the product.
"But as far as I can recall, there were no rain-related stoppages during last month," said the Santos spokeswoman.
Paranagua officials could not say when operations last stopped because of rain.
